Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Defect-engineered Nanocarbons for Electrochemical Energy Storage

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this program is to develop scalable nanomanufacturing technologies for the production of high-energy density electrochemical capacitors, consisting of nanostructured electrodes with controllable charged defect density and redox polymers. This aspect of nanoscale engineering is transformative in that the constituent electrodes have a unique combination of both double-layer and redox capacitance, with very large area leading to higher energy density and low electrical resistance for enhanced power density.

Intellectual merit: The intellectual merit is defined through the scope of the work, which aims to integrate from the bottom up, all the necessary processes for a carbon based high energy storage density device. This includes nanostructure synthesis through a roll-to-roll process, plasma processing for electrical charge introduction, in-line metrology to provide real-time monitoring of the structural properties, for the ultimate purpose of deploying fully functional capacitors. Fundamental insights into electrochemical mechanisms and material interactions will be obtained and applied to the development of proof-of-concept devices and prototype systems.

Broader impacts: The broader impacts are the development of high-energy density carbon nanomaterials compatible with large-scale device fabrication technologies, and extending the reach of nanotechnology to budding scientists and the wider community. The potential applications for high-energy electrochemical capacitors range from small-scale portable electronics (requiring high power density and large cycle life) to large-format energy management. In addition to promoting graduate and undergraduate education and training on nanotechnology and process integration, outreach activities will promote novel energy technologies.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The increasing global energy demands have spurred a rigorous search for new renewable energy sources. In recent times, fuel cells, photovoltaic devices/solar cells and various other renewable energy sources have received much attention, and are all promising candidates for clean energy production. However, today’s batteries and capacitors, which are the main components for energy storage, cannot meet the world’s demand for combined power and energy densities. e.g., in applications that require a rapid change in energy such as power drills, cranes, elevators and hybrid electric vehicles. One of the main drawbacks of a battery is that it cannot provide its stored energy quickly; in other words it lacks power. So, supercapacitors have come into vogue as they are capable of delivering their energy very quickly. However, supercapacitors cannot store much energy, and therefore it is desirable to use porous carbon electrodes to enhance the energy of supercapacitors. With porous carbon electrodes, the hope is that more ions (that are present in the electrolyte) can interact with the electrode, and thusly increase the energy of the supercapacitor. In order to push such technologies towards practical use, carbon based nanomaterials that can store and appropriately discharge the energy from traditional renewable energy sources, and scalable nanomanufacturing technologies for large scale production of such devices are needed.

 

This project proved transformational from the point of view of energy storage as it developed (a) scalable methods for manufacturing electrodes comprised of high-surface area, free-standing carbon nanomaterial electrodes,  (b) processes to tailor such electrode properties via defect-engineering or through incorporating electroactive conducting polymers into nanocarbon for hybrid electrodes, and (c) fundamental understanding and insights into optimal device geometry and electrochemical mechanisms in hybrid electrochemical devices, e.g., overcoming the inherent quantum capacitance associated with nanocarbon electrodes. The combined use of nanocarbons and polymers in an asymmetric configuration, with an aim to maximize both the energy and power density in a single device is novel, and has advanced our knowledge in scalable synthesis of low dimensional materials at large. It has also enabled the energy storage industry to add a new dimension through the use of optimized capacitors.

A close collaboration with industry provided students the opportunity to understand issues involved in device manufacture and fostered creative engineering attitudes in the workforce of the next generation. Lastly, this project resulted in the following patent: “Polymer-Nanocarbon Composites, Methods of Making Composites, and Energy Storage Devices Including the Composite”, M. E. Roberts, A. M. Rao, R. Podila, and R. Emmett, US Patent #9552929 (2017).


Last Modified: 01/10/2018
Modified by: Apparao M Rao

In recent times, fuel cells, photovoltaic devices/solar cells and various other renewable energy sources have received much attention, and are all promising candidates for clean energy production. However, today?s batteries and capacitors, which are the main components for energy storage, cannot meet the world?s demand for combined power and energy densities. e.g., in applications that require a rapid change in energy such as power drills, cranes, elevators and hybrid electric vehicles. One of the main drawbacks of a battery is that it cannot provide its stored energy quickly; in other words it lacks power. So, supercapacitors have come into vogue as they are capable of delivering their energy very quickly. However, supercapacitors cannot store much energy, and therefore it is desirable to use porous carbon electrodes to enhance the energy of supercapacitors. With porous carbon electrodes, the hope is that more ions (that are present in the electrolyte) can interact with the electrode, and thusly increase the energy of the supercapacitor. In order to push such technologies towards practical use, carbon based nanomaterials that can store and appropriately discharge the energy from traditional renewable energy sources, and scalable nanomanufacturing technologies for large scale production of such devices are needed. This project proved transformational from the point of view of energy storage as it developed (a) scalable methods for manufacturing electrodes comprised of high-surface area, free-standing carbon nanomaterial electrodes, (b) processes to tailor such electrode properties via defect-engineering or through incorporating electroactive conducting polymers into nanocarbon for hybrid electrodes, and (c) fundamental understanding and insights into optimal device geometry and electrochemical mechanisms in hybrid electrochemical devices, e.g., overcoming the inherent quantum capacitance associated with nanocarbon electrodes. The combined use of nanocarbons and polymers in an asymmetric configuration, with an aim to maximize both the energy and power density in a single device is novel, and has advanced our knowledge in scalable synthesis of low dimensional materials at large. It has also enabled the energy storage industry to add a new dimension through the use of optimized capacitors.
